note_models.name: Cloze

fields: {{c1::Complexity}} means something which comprises parts in {{c3::intricate arrangement}}, making it more difficult to {{c2::predict}} and introduces {{c2::uncertainty}}.
{{c1::Complicated}} means something which is not {{c2::simple}}, but still easy to {{c2::predict}} if you put enough effort into understanding.
The difference between {{c2::complexity}} and {{c2::complicatedness}} is {{c1::predictability}}.
A {{c1::system}} is a set of {{c2::interrelated components}} working together to {{c2::accomplish a common purpose}}.

A system can be described by its {{c2::elements}} and the {{c3::relationships}} between them.

What is outside the system is called the {{c1::environment}}.

We define subsystems as well, which are subsets of {{c2::elements}} in the system which retains the {{c3::relationships}} between all {{c2::elements}}.
From the stakeholders' point of view, projects arise from two things: {{c1::needs}} and {{c1::opportunities}}.

Needs that give birth to projects arise from:

{{c1::
Functional deficiency
e.g. something that detects wildfires, which would be something that serves a totally new function.
::Func...}}

{{c2::
Operational deficiency
e.g. adding communication bandwidth. Communication already exists, but adding communication bandwidth makes communicating easier.
::Oper...}}

{{c3::
Changes in legislation and regulation.
These changes may mean you need to develop a new product because you are no longer allowed to use nuclear power as an alternative to Teslas.
::Leg...}}

Opportunities that give birth to projects arise from:

{{c1::
Technology fusion or breakthrough
For example, if a new type of battery is developed that can store much more energy, there's gonna be a lot of stuff where this could possibly be applied.
::Break...}}

{{c2::
Discoveries
For example, if we discover water on Mars, there'll be additional space projects going to Mars.
::Dis...}}

{{c3::
Market demand
For example, if the world suddenly gets a weird fetish for horseshit, then there are gonna be opportunities for you to design projects where horseshit can be mass-produced due to the market demand.
::Mar...}}
{{c1::Requirements}} are {{c2::"shall statements"}} and are singular documented needs of {{c3::what a particular product shall do or be}}.
{{c1::Stakeholders}} are {{c2::all parties affected or which can be affected by the system.}}
Stakeholder {{c1::needs}} are about the {{c2::"What"}}, while {{c1::requirements}} are about the {{c2::"How"}}.

A {{c1::constraint}} is a restriction on {{c2::the degree of freedom in providing a solution}}.

A {{c1::constraint}} can be formulated as a requirement.
The Systems Engineering universe is established by {{c1::technical performance::perf...}}, {{c2::cost::c...}} and {{c3::schedule::sch...}}. All three dimensions are interconnected via {{c4::risk}}.
In the V-model of the systems engineering process, requirements are {{c1::decomposed downwards into smaller requirements::acted upon}}, and the designs are {{c2::integrated upwards::acted upon}}.

In the discovery tour used to go from needs to requirements, the cut-off point from {{c2::non-technical}} to {{c2::technical}} is between {{c1::stakeholder requirements}} and {{c1::system requirements}}.
A {{c1::requirement}} is a {{c2::condition which must be complied with.}}

A {{c1::mission need statement}} describes in general terms the {{c2::need}} and {{c2::mission}} in a single, clear and concise sentence. It describes {{c3::what the product does}}, not {{c3::what it is or how it is done}}.
{{c1::Killer}} requirements drive the design to an {{c2::unacceptable}} extent.
{{c1::Driving}} requirements drive the design {{c4::more than average::to some extent}}.
{{c1::Key}} requirements are requirements of {{c2::primary importance to the customer::related to customer}}.

The 12 requirements on requirements are the following:


1. Each requirement shall have a unique {{c1::identifier (an abbreviated code-name so that you can refer to them).}}

2. This {{c1::identifier}} shall not be {{c2::re-used}} in the event the requirement is deleted.

3. The requirement shall be {{c3::unambiguous::un...}}.

4. The inclusion of {{c4::essential::ess...}} and {{c5::design-to::des...}}, requirements shall be complete.

5. Each sentence shall include {{c6::one::number of}} requirement(s).

6. Terms that are {{c8::vague}} or not {{c8::verifiable}} such as {{c7::"or, etc., appropriate"}} shall not be used.

7. Each requirement shall be {{c9::unique::un...}}.

8. The content of a requirement shall not be interpretable {{c10::in more than one way::somehow}}.

9. A requirement shall be {{c11::verifiable::ver...}}.

10. A requirement shall be {{c12::consistent::con...}} , i.e. it shall be ensured that there is no {{c16::conflict between any two requirements in a specification}}.

11. The content of a requirement shall not include the {{c13::reason for the requirement}} or a {{c13::description of the design}}.
{{c13::Rationales}} and {{c13::design descriptions}} shall be documented separately.

12. The requirement shall be {{c14::complete, ::com...}} i.e. {{c15::it shall be ensured that all functions and performance items are defined, which are required during the foreseen life cycle of the system}}.

Requirements can be verified in four ways:

1. {{c1::Inspection:
for example, a requirement that something shall be 27 cm long can be easily verified by inspection.::In...}}

2. {{c2::Analysis:
some requirements are harder to verify. For example, if something is supposed to have a probability of 80% then of course you can do a lot of tests to check whether this probability is more or less correct, but this gets rather costly if you are fore example testing nukes. In those cases, a very detailed mathematical analysis may be more in place.::An...}}

3. {{c3::Demonstration:
for example, if a requirement is that a car is supposed to be able to go faster than 100 km/h, then you can easily demonstrate this by just having the car drive faster than 100 km/h.::Dem...}}

4. {{c4::Test:
for example, if a requirement is that a car has a drag coefficient of 0.2 , then you can test this in a wind tunnel.
::Te...}}
In engineering, a {{c1::function}} describes the {{c2::requested behaviour}} of a system. When you formulate {{c1::functions}}, always use a verb.

{{c2::Functional break-down structures}} are {{c1::AND::logical operation}} trees: each element of the tree is the {{c1::sum}} of all elements below it. 

They {{c3::don't::do/don't}} say anything about sequence.
{{c1::Functional Flow Block Diagrams}} are {{c2::multi-tier::multi...}}, {{c3::time-sequenced::time...}}, {{c4::step-by-step::step...}} diagrams of a system's {{c1::functional flow}}.
{{c1::N2 charts}} are a grid of processes where {{c2::horizontal}} flows are {{c3::outputs}} and {{c2::vertical}} flows are {{c3::inputs}}.
{{c1::Design trades}} is the process of {{c2::finding, analysing, and selecting certain concepts ("How?") that can fulfill the requirements ("What?")}}
{{c1::Design option trees}} are used to list out all the possible design options.

Some guidelines for design option trees are:

Each element has {{c1::one or more::quantity}} descendant and nothing else.

Every single {{c2::possibility::p...}} is included.

Use {{c3::"anything else"}} as temporary placeholder
If you get stuck, you have a solution and can continue on until you've written down {{c4::"anything else"}} literally everywhere, then you have to start thinking.

The trade-off process consists of the following steps:

1. {{c1::
Strawman concepts are used to generate the design tree.
They're called strawman concepts because a strawman just forms the skeleton essentially, it's not meant as a super-detailed concept so it allows a team of designers to have discussions about it.
Both familiar and new concepts may be included.
::Straw...}}

2. {{c2::
Empty concepts are eliminated.
These are concepts that were named for the sake of completeness, but for which no implementation can be found.
::Em...}}

3. {{c3::
Infeasible concepts are eliminated.
Stuff that violates laws of nature or are just grossly impractical can be crossed out now.
::Inf...}}

4. {{c4::"Maybe" concepts are generated.::May...}}

5. {{c5::
Future concepts that can't be analysed or developed yet are discarded.
However, these are documented, so that people in the future, when there's more advanced technology, can look into it.
::Fut...}}

6. {{c6::
Weakest points of each survivor are listed.
Ones that are truly weak are then discarded.
::Weak...}}

7. {{c7::Feasible, proposed concepts are left over.::Fea...}}

After the trade-off process is finished and only proposed, feasible concepts remain, a final design choice must be made.
This is done by defining some selection criteria coming from three sources:

1. {{c1::Killer::bad}} requirements identified in initial requirements analysis
2. {{c2::Key::good}} requirements identified in initial requirements analysis
3. {{c3::Other system-level::at some level}} requirements in which candidate concepts differ significantly
4. Additional selection criteria from analysing {{c4::strawman::str...}} design

For the trade-off table containing the selection criteria and their respective weights, certain rules apply:

Options go in the {{c2::left column::location}}, criteria go in the {{c2::top row::location}}.

The column {{c3::width::w...}} should be proportional to the {{c3::weight::w...}} of its criteria.

Write the {{c1::reason for judgement::rea...}} in the box/cell.

Define the {{c4::score classes::clas...}} clearly
{{c4::e.g. excellent, good, correctable deficiencies, unacceptable. Use colour because maybe your table will be used in an oral presentation. }}
{{c1::Verification}} is the {{c2::proof of compliance}} with design solution {{c2::specifications}} and descriptive documents.
{{c1::Validation}} is the proof that {{c2::the product accomplishes the intended purpose}} based on {{c2::stakeholder expectations}}.

{{c1::Verification}} is checking whether something does what you want it to do.

{{c1::Validation}} is checking whether what you wanted it to do is correct.

Verification and Validation aims at answering the following questions:

1. {{c1::Requirements::Req...}} validation:
{{c1::are these the right requirements?}}

2. {{c2::Model::Mo...}} validation:
{{c2::are the models (supporting design and verification) correct?}}

3. {{c3::Product::Pro...}} verification:
{{c3::does the product meet the requirements?}}

4. {{c4::Product::Pro...}} validation:
{{c4::did we build the right product?}}

5. {{c5::Flight::Fli...}} certification:
{{c5::is the system ready to fly?}}

Requirement validation checks whether the requirements are correct.
This can be done by use of the VALID method.

Requirements ought to be:

{{c1::Verifiable::Ve...}}
{{c2::Achievable::Ach...}}
{{c3::Logical::Lo...}}
{{c4::Integral::Int...}}
{{c5::Definitive, i.e. unambiguous.::Def...}}

Model validation is checking whether the models are correct. There are several types of models:

{{c1::
Physical/hardware
e.g. think of the paper buildings that architects like to make because they're not CATIA-pros.
::Phy...}}

{{c2::
Graphical
e.g. think of when you make a design in CATIA to check whether the actuator actually works and doesn't suddenly go through other objects.
::Gra...}}

{{c3::
Mathematical/software
e.g. think back to SVV.
::Ma...}}

{{c4::
Statistical
e.g. orbital debris simulation.
::Sta...}}

Models can be validated by:

{{c1::Experience::Ex...}} with application of similar models in similar circumstances.

{{c2::Analysis::An...}} showing that the elements of the model are of necessity correct and are correctly integrated.

{{c3::Comparison::Com...}} with test casing in the form of independent models of proven validity or actual test data.

Product validation is the process of checking that you have designed the right thing to do the mission.
The focus is not so much on requirements, but on what needs to happen in practice.


Possible product validation techniques are:

{{c1::End-to-end information system::Info...}} testing:
{{c1::this shows the compatibility of project information systems, i.e. all the data flows to the correct places at the correct times.}}

{{c2::Mission scenario::Mis...}} tests:
certain scenarios that can be encountered in real life are simulated to demonstrate that the flight hardware and software can perform it, not taking into account the real timeline of the product.

{{c3::Operations readiness::Op...}} tests:
it is demonstrated that all elements of the ground segment can accomplish the mission plan using the real timeline.

{{c4::Stress::Str...}}-testing and simulation:
the system is subjected to unexpected conditions to show its robustness in performance and fault conditions.

Planning verification and validation consists of 7 steps:

1. Establish {{c1::objectives::obj...}}.

2. Establish the {{c2::concept::co...}} of how to {{c2::meet the objective::related to objective}}.

3. Determine the required {{c3::inputs::i...}} and {{c3::outputs::o...}}.

4. {{c4::Plan::P...}} the activity: how does the process look like; when is what needed and done?

5. {{c5::Document::Do...}} and {{c6::iterate::it...}}.

6. Execute the {{c7::verification::v...}} and {{c7::validation::v...}}.

7. Document the {{c8::result::re...}} and {{c8::process::pro...}}, and iterate if necessary.

Class II weight estimation is used to find the weight of {{c1::component groups}} in a design, and allows the user to evaluate the sensitivity of the weight to a number of relevant {{c1::design parameters}}.

In the Class II estimation of the weight of a wing:
[$]W_{\text {wing }}=0.0051\left(W_{d g} N_{z}\right)^{0.557} S_{w}^{0.649} A^{0.5}(t / c)_{\text {root }}^{-0.4}(1+\lambda)^{0.1} \cdot(\cos \Lambda)^{-1.0} S_{c s w}^{0.1}[/$]


[$]W_{dg}[/$] is the {{c4::design gross weight}}

[$]N_z[/$] is the {{c5::ultimate load factor, or [$]1.5 \cdot n_{max}[/$], where [$]n_{max}[/$] is the maximum design load factor}}

[$]S_w[/$] is the {{c6::wing surface}}

[$]A[/$] is the wing {{c7::
aspect ratio
Increasing the aspect ratio (with constant wing surface) increases the wing weight because {{c1::it 'thins' out the wing, making it have a higher wing span. This increases the bending load thus increasing the required structural integrity.}}
}}

[$](t/c)_{root}[/$] is the {{c9::
thickness ratio at the root
Thicker airfoils decrease the wing weight because {{c8::the structure will be reinforced in bending, leading to less structural mass being needed.}}
}}

[$]\lambda[/$] is the {{c10::
taper ratio
A higher taper ratio increases the wing weight because {{c2::the wing tip will have an increased chord, which increases the loading near the wing tip, increasing the bending load, and hence increasing the require structural strength and weight.}}
}}

[$]\Lambda[/$] is the {{c11::
sweep ratio
Higher sweep ratios increase wing weight because {{c3::of the added torsional forces, requiring a stronger and heavier structure.}}
}}

[$]S_{csw}[/$] is the {{c12::control surface area}}

The definition of the {{c3::load factor}} is:

[$]n = {{c1::[/$] [$]\frac{L}{W}[/$]}} [$]=[/$] {{c2::[$]\frac{q \cdot C_L}{W/S}[/$]}}

In the given maneuver load diagram:

The line connecting points A and D is the {{c1::maximum prescribed load factor [$]n_{max}[/$]}}

The line connecting points H and F is the {{c1::minimum prescribed load factor [$]n_{min}[/$]}}
{{c1::The value of [$]n_{min}[/$] is typically smaller than [$]m_{max}[/$] because {{c2::load factors smaller than -1 mean you are barreling down at the Earth (not good).}}}}

[$]V_S[/$] is the {{c3::stall velocity}}
The load factor here is 1 because {{c4::you fly at [$]{C_L}_{max}[/$] and lift equals weight.}}

[$]V_A[/$] is the {{c5::minimum speed at which you can reach [$]n_{max}[/$]}} and is called {{c5::the maneuver speed}}

[$]V_D[/$] is the {{c6::maximum speed that can be reached}}, and is called {{c6::the dive speed}}.

The line between the origin and points A and H is curved because {{c7::of the quadratic relationship between speed and the load factor (see equation in the figure).}}

When performing gust load diagram calculations:

When a gust with velocity [$]v[/$] in the direction of the airflow (which has velocity [$]V[/$]) and a velocity [$]u[/$] in a direction perpendicular to the airflow (upwards), the angle of attack [$]\alpha[/$] is increased by:

[$]\Delta \alpha = [/$] {{c1::[$]\arctan{\frac{u}{V+v} } \approx \frac{u}{V}[/$]}}
This is assuming [$]v<<V[/$] and using the small-angle approximation.

When performing gust load diagram calculations:

For an angle of attack increase [$]\Delta \alpha = \frac{u}{V}[/$] from a gust with upwards velocity [$]u[/$],

the increase in lift [$]\Delta L[/$] is
{{c1::[$]\frac{1}{2} \rho V^{2} S C_{L_{\alpha} } \Delta \alpha=\frac{1}{2} \rho V S C_{L_{\alpha} } u[/$]}}

For the given gust load diagram:


[$]V_B[/$] is the speed of {{c1::highest possible angle of attack}}

[$]V_C[/$] is the speed of {{c2::cruise}}

[$]V_D[/$] is the speed of {{c3::dive}}

For wind gust diagram calculations, the change in load factor can be calculated using
[$]\Delta n =[/$] {{c3::[$]\frac{\rho V C_{L_{\alpha}} u}{2(W / S)}[/$]}}

where [$]u = K\cdot \hat{u}[/$]

[$]K[/$] is {{c1::a correctional factor depending on the speed regime}}
[$]\hat{u}[/$] is {{c2::the gust speed specified by the CS}}

The procedure for balancing an aircraft (within the scope of SEAD) is:

1. Determine the {{c1::center of gravity}} of the aircraft at {{c2::operative empty}} weight for the assumed {{c3::tail}} size and {{c3::longitudinal wing}} position.

2. Add the c.g. variations caused by non-fixed items, such as {{c4::payload}} and {{c4::fuel}}. This results in {{c5::loading}} diagrams.

3. Check the maximum {{c7::c.g. range}} against the allowable most {{c7::aft}} and {{c7::forward}} c.g. position, which results in the {{c6::scissor}} plot.

4. If necessary, the tail size and longitudinal wing position are adjusted, and iteration from point 1 occurs.

If the OEW c.g. is unknown, but the wing and fuselage group c.g.s are, the OEW c.g. can be computed using:

{{c1::[$]x_{c . g . O E W}=\frac{x_{c . g_{\text {wing }}} \cdot W_{\text {wing }}+x_{c . g . \text { fuselage }} \cdot W_{\text {fuselage }}}{W_{\text {wing }}+W_{\text {fuselage }}}[/$]}}
In c.g. calculations, the wing group consists of all components that {{c1::move along with the wing.}}
This includes the wing structure, control surfaces, wing mounted engines, fuel (if it is stored in the wing), and the main landing gear.
To obtain small {{c2::tail loads,}} the center of gravity is always located close to the {{c1::wing aerodynamic center}}, so that the moment arm of the weight is small.

When adding an item to the aircraft, the new c.g. can be calculated with:

[$]x_{c . g_{\text {new }}}=[/$] {{c1::[$]\frac{W_{\text {old }} \cdot x_{c . g \cdot o l d}+W_{\text {item }} \cdot x_{c . g \cdot \text { tiem }}}{W_{\text {old }}+W_{\text {item }}}[/$]}}

In the given loading (potato) diagram:
The black bars touching the most forward and aft c.g. positions indicate the {{c1::2}}% safety margin to account for {{c2::passengers moving, the landing gear retracting, etc}}.

On the ground, there are some loading requirements which must be fulfilled:

The {{c1::main gear}} must always sit {{c2::behind::ahead of/behind}} the {{c3::maximum aft c.g. position}}.
Otherwise you tip back.

The nose gear should not be overloaded.
It should carry less than {{c4::15}}% of the MTOW, to not {{c7::spoil the braking efficiency}} and to {{c8::allow for steering during breaking}}.
However, it also shouldn't be too little (more than {{c5::8}}% is required), to prevent {{c6::the nose wheel from providing little directional control}}.

If needed, the wing can be shifted front and back to move the c.g. in certain ways relative to the mean aerodynamic center.

If the wing is shifted forward:
relative to the mean aerodynamic center, the c.g. will shift {{c1::backward}}, as the fuselage moves {{c1::backwards}} relative to the wing.

If the wing is shifted backward:
relative to the mean aerodynamic center, the c.g. will shift {{c1::forward}}, as the fuselage moves {{c1::forward}} relative to the wing.

There are three stability and control requirements:

- Ensure equilibrium of {{c1::moments}} in steady flight. This is the {{c2::trim}} condition.
- Ensure {{c3::stability}} around this state of equilibrium. That is, a {{c4::disturbance}} is restored.
- Generate forces for {{c5::manoeuvring, i.e. control.}}
Stability and control in aircraft are {{c1::inversely}} correlated.

The aircraft c.g. must always stay {{c2::in front of::in front of/behind}} the neutral point.

The neutral point is the point {{c1::...through which the resultant change in lift acts when the angle of attack is changed.}}

Then if the angle of attack, the resultant change in lift will act through the neutral point and cause an nose-down moment, decreasing the angle of attack again. Thus, the aircraft is stable, etc. Note that this means that [$]C_{m_{\alpha}}[/$] should be negative as well.

Let's analyse the above situation in a bit more detail. Suppose we experience a change in angle of attack.
Let's then compute the change in moment around the neutral point.
By definition of the neutral point, the change in moment around it should be zero, as the neutral point is the point through which the resultant change in lift force acts.

Thus, we must have

{{c1::[$]\Delta L_{A-h}\left(\bar{x}_{n p}-\bar{x}_{a c}\right)-\Delta L_{h}\left(\bar{x}_{h}-\bar{x}_{n p}\right)=0[/$]::relating [$]\Delta L_{A-h}[/$] and [$]\Delta L_{h}[/$]}}

where

[$]\Delta L_{A-h}=[/$] {{c2::[$]C_{L_{\alpha_{A-h} } } \Delta \alpha \frac{1}{2} \rho V^{2} S[/$]::in terms of [$]\Delta \alpha[/$]}}

and

[$]\Delta L_{h}=[/$] {{c3::[$]C_{L_{\alpha_{h} } }(\Delta \alpha-\Delta \epsilon) \frac{1}{2} \rho V_{h}^{2} S_{h}[/$]::in terms of [$]\Delta \alpha[/$] }}
The bar on top of [$]\bar{x}_{c . g .}[/$] indicates that {{c1::it has been divided by [$]\hat{c}[/$]}}.

The center of gravity must lie {{c2::ahead}} of the neutral point. This means that there is a {{c4::stability margin}} between them (usually taken as {{c3::5}}%) and this relation is expressed as:

{{c1::[$]\bar{x}_{c . g .}=\bar{x}_{n p}-S M[/$]}}

In order to get the {{c5::longitudinal stability}} curve for the scissor plot (used to {{c4::size the horizontal tail}}), we rewrite our expressions for

the {{c1::zero change in moment around the neutral point}}

and

the {{c2::stability margin distance between the center of gravity and the neutral point}}

as a function of {{c3::[$]\frac{S_{h}}{S}[/$]}}

There are two things we can do to make the aircraft more stable:

Shift {{c2::the graph to the right}}, which can be achieved by moving {{c3::[$]\bar{x}_{a c}[/$] back}}

Decrease {{c1::the slope of the curve}}

When trying to move [$]\bar{x}_{a c}[/$] backwards in order to increase stability, there are several contributions to take into account:

- The main {{c1::wing}} aerodynamic center, which depends on the {{c2::speed}}: it moves {{c3::forward}} with increasing {{c2::speed}}.

- The fuselage has two corrective terms:

The nose is destabilising: the nose essentially also acts as airfoil.
Thus, if the {{c4::angle of attack}} is {{c5::increased}}, more {{c6::lift}} will be produced at the nose, and thus an additional {{c7::pitch up moment}} is created, thus destabilising the whole happening.

The lift loss at the {{c8::wing-fuselage crossing}} is {{c9::stabilising::stabilizing/destabilizing}}, as it means less lift is generated at the wing (which generates a {{c10::pitch-up moment}} around the {{c11::neutral point}}).

- The engine nacelles have a (de)stablizing effect, depending on the configuration:

If they are {{c13::wing}}-mounted, they are {{c12::destablising::stabilising/destabilising}}, as the nacelles also effectively generate lift {{c15::in front of::in front of/behind}} the neutral point, causing a pitch-up attitude.

If they are {{c14::fuselage}}-mounted, they are {{c12::stablising::stabilising/destabilising}}, as they essentially create a lift {{c16::behind::in front of/behind}} of the neutral point.

To increase the longitudinal stability, we can decrease the gradient of the curve. As apparent from the fraction in front of [$]\bar{x}_{c . g .}[/$] in the equation:

[$]\frac{S_{h}}{S}=\frac{1}{\frac{C_{L_{\alpha_{h}}}}{C_{L_{\alpha_{A-h}}}}\left(1-\frac{d \epsilon}{d \alpha}\right) \frac{l_{h}}{\bar{c}}\left(\frac{V_{h}}{V}\right)^{2}} \bar{x}_{c . g .}-\frac{\bar{x}_{a c}-0.05}{\frac{C_{L_{\alpha_{h}}}}{C_{L_{\alpha_{A-h}}}}\left(1-\frac{d \epsilon}{d \alpha}\right) \frac{l_{h}}{\bar{c}}\left(\frac{V_{h}}{V}\right)^{2}}[/$]

we see that the following parameters affect the slope of the graph:

- [$]V_{h} / V[/$]: the higher, the {{c1::more::more/less}} stable.
- [$]C_{L_{\alpha_{h}}}[/$]: the higher, the {{c2::more::more/less}} stable.
- [$]C_{L_{\alpha_{A-h}}}[/$]: the higher, the {{c3::less::more/less}} stable.
- [$]l_{h}[/$]: the higher, the higher, the {{c4::more::more/less}} stable.
- [$]d \epsilon / d \alpha[/$]: the higher, the {{c5::less::more/less}} stable.

With the given image:

In the subsonic speed regime, {{c3::increasing::increasing/decreasing}} M also moves the neutral point {{c2::forward}} because of the {{c4::decreasing magnitude of [$]C_{m_{\alpha}}[/$]}}.

At M=0.8, we enter the transonic speed regime, and {{c5::shockwaves}} begin to appear over the wing, significantly decreasing the {{c6::lift production}} over it, resulting in {{c8::less::more/less}} {{c7::downwash}} at the tail. This is why the [$]C_{m_{\alpha}}[/$] increases in magnitude again, and the aircraft is said to 'tuck under'.

Aircraft flying at high subsonic regimes have a Mach trimmer, which modifies the {{c9::horizontal tail}} setting (the {{c10::angle of attack}} of it) accordingly to the speed, such that it does not produce too much {{c1::lift}} suddenly.

Why do we have a 5% stability margin?

Well, first, there are also other {{c2::neutral points}}, e.g. when you're flying stick-free, which also need to be stable, obviously.

Furthermore, there's a minimum {{c1::control force (or feel)}} required, as stipulated by CS requirements:
if the c.g. is very aft, the stability becomes less, but the controllability becomes very good:
this means that only very little force is required to manoeuvre the aircraft.

This is not really desired: you don't want it to happen that when you accidentally shift the stick slightly, you're immediately causing the aircraft to crash and that everybody dies.
